title: Charging - transfer between 1 nC and -3 nC spheres

content.question: Two identical conducting spheres have different charges. One sphere has a charge of <math alttext="positive 1 nanocoulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>, and the other sphere has a charge of <math alttext="negative 3 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. The two spheres are brought into contact and then separated. What is the magnitude of charge that is transferred between the spheres, and what is the most accurate description of how to calculate the magnitude of the transferred charge?

choices.label: <math alttext="2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. This is half of the difference in the charges on the spheres.
<math alttext="2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. This is the average magnitude of the charges on the spheres.
<math alttext="4 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. This is the difference in the charges on the spheres.
<math alttext="4 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. This is the sum of the magnitudes of the charges on the spheres.

content.answer: <math alttext="2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. This is half of the difference in the charges on the spheres.
